EagleHawk Field Services LLC
Blackhawk Central Gas Treating Facility
Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

EagleHawk Field Services LLC (EagleHawk) has a standing commitment to worker and public safety, demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention.  These resources include safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the process at the Blackhawk Gas Treating Facility (Blackhawk or Facility) and training of operations personnel and contractors. EagleHawk implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  EagleHawk places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspections and regularly training responsible personnel.  Should a release occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release, and/or mitigate any off-site consequences.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Blackhawk Central, located in DeWitt County, Texas, is owned and operated by EagleHawk.  Blackhawk Central is a natural gas processing plant comprised of natural gas liquid recovery, natural gas liquids fractionation, and natural gas treatment and compression equipment.  The natural gas liquid recovery equipment is designed to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas.  Produced gas and liquids are delivered to the Facility from gathering systems and pipelines.  The Facility process produces natural gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate.  The Facility equipment operates to separate, stabilize, treat (as necessary to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide), compress (gas), dehydrate (gas), store (natural gas liquids and stabilized condensate), and transfer gas, natural gas liquids, and stabilized condensate to sales.  Natural gas is transported by pipeline from the Facility, and natural gas liquids and

stabilized condensate are transported by cargo tank motor vehicles.

The listed flammable substance above the threshold quantities at Blackhawk Central is a flammable mixture containing methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane and pentane.  No toxic substances are in the process.  The Facility is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation and is classified as a Program 3 process per the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program (RMP). 

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

The following summary of the accident prevention program in place at Blackhawk Central addresses each element of the accident prevention program and describes the management system in place to implement the program.  The accident prevention program at the Facility equally covers all individually listed flammable substances and regulated flammable mixture. 

	Employee Participation

Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the Facility's accident prevention program is a critical component of the overall objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of a flammable substance.  Employee involvement helps to ensure that all perspectives regarding accident prevention are considered for implementation.  Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding all aspects of safety and health issues concerning employees, contractors and the public.

EagleHawk strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through, for example, regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail-gate safety meetings, hazard communications, safety suggestions, incident reporting system, and special training programs such as emergency response training and first aid training.

EagleHawk actively seeks employee involvement in the development and implementation of all

accident prevention activities through the appropriate programs.  Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings and/or during special training sessions, if necessary.  Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, comments or suggestions forward for open discussion.

	Process Safety Information

Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis.  The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by Facility personnel, the process hazard analysis team, and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan.  Process safety information is readily available to all employees.  EagleHawk maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration.
Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS).

EagleHawk also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at Blackhawk Central.  This information includes but is not limited to materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.  This information in combination with written procedures and trained personnel provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Blackh

awk Central has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, the process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

EagleHawk primarily uses the hazard and operability analysis (HAZOP) and What-if/Checklist techniques to perform these evaluations.  The analyses are conducted using a team of EagleHawk personnel who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise, and may include third parties.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures.  The team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are needed.  Any identified risks are promptly addressed.  Resolution of each finding is documented and records of the analyses are retained.

To ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not significantly deviate from the original design safety features, the facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years unless review is warranted sooner due to a significant change at the Facility.  Once again, the reviews are documented and records of the review are retained.

	Operating Procedures

Blackhawk Central maintains written procedures at the Facility that address various modes of process operations such as: (1) initial start-up; (2) normal operations; (3) temporary operations; (4) emergency shutdown;  (5) emergency operations; (6) normal shutdown; and (7) startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown.  Operating procedures are reviewed periodically and as operational changes are introduced and annually certified as current and accurate.  Both operators and technical staff participate in the review and certification process. 

Operating

procedures provide current, clearly written instructions for operating the process.  Instructions include applicable safety precautions and appropriate information on safety implications.  Operating procedures ensure that all employees operate the process in a prescribed, consistent, and safe manner.  

	Training

EagleHawk has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the process at Blackhawk Central.  New employees receive basic training in gas and fractionation operations.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every three years.  All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.

	Contractors

EagleHawk uses contractors during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner; (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills; (3) are aware of the hazards of their workplace; (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency; (5) understand and follow site-specific safety rules; and (6) inform Facility personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation session that covers: (1) a process overview; (2) information about the safety and health hazards; (3) emergency response plan requirements; and (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work.  In addition, EagleHawk evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process.  EagleHawk personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

	Pre-Startup Safe

ty Review (PSSR)

EagleHawk conducts a PSSR on any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

	Mechanical Integrity

EagleHawk has practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment at Blackhawk Central.  The aspects of this program include: (1) training; (2) written procedures; (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  These activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.

EagleHawk incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

	Safe Work Practices

EagleHawk has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work); and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures, along with training of affec

ted personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the Facility.

	Management of Change

EagleHawk has a comprehensive system to manage change to the process at Blackhawk Central.  Changes to process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regulated substances in the process, and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Reviews ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate a change.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are notified of changes and, if necessary, trained on the changes.
	
        Incident Investigation

EagleHawk promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action for the prevention of the same or a similar incident.  Findings and recommendations are documented and are forwarded to Facility management for resolution.

	Compliance Audits

EagleHawk periodically conducts audits to determine the implementation of the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  An audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until resolution.  The resolution of each finding is documented.  The two most recent audit reports are retained.

	Specific Prevention Steps

Hazards in the process at Bla

ckhawk Central are continually managed to ensure safe operations.  The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the Facility are described below.

		Uniform Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP-covered process at Blackhawk Central.  These prevention programs are designed and implemented to prevent potential accidental release scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.

		Specialized Safety Features

Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation and maintenance of Blackhawk Central to help prevent, quickly detect and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process: 

Release Detection 
   Hydrocarbon (hazardous gas) detectors and alarms

Release Containment and Control
   Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
   Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
   Automatic shutdown systems for specific process
   Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases
   Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
   Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) system

Release Mitigation
   Hand-held and wheeled cart fire extinguishers 
   Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures
   Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)

Five Year Accident History
	
EagleHawk has an excellent record of accident prevention.  There have been no large or small accidental releases resulting in injuries to site personnel or contractors, or offsite consequences at the Facility. 

Emergency Response Program Information

EagleHawk maintains written emergency procedures at the Facility to protect worker and public safety and the environment

.  These include procedures for a fire or explosion and notification of local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release.  Employees are trained on the emergency procedures and the emergency procedures are updated when the process or Facility is modified.  Changes to the emergency procedures are administered through the Management of Change process.

The overall emergency program for Blackhawk Central is coordinated with the DeWitt County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Coordination includes periodic meetings to communicate the Facility operations, contact information, and response activities.  EagleHawk has 24/7 communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., DeWitt County LEPC Chairman, DeWitt County Sheriff, and Cuero Fire Department).  The LEPC would assist the Facility, as requested, to notify the public, control traffic, and facilitate response to an incident.  EagleHawk provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated flammable substances in the Facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

EagleHawk tracks and resolves all PHA recommendations.  All personnel, employees, and contractors are encouraged to notify their supervisor of any changes or modifications to the Facility that could result in improved safety.  Plans to improve the safety include:  1)  Installation of additional process controls, such as tank gauges and/or alarms; and, 2)  Installation of process area detection systems.
